section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to welcome children to pre-K, engage children by singing “The Alphabet Song,” and introduce vocabulary (proud).
Begin Story Time by introducing the literacy mascot, Pablo the Parrot, and the book and asking, What do children like to do?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Participate in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Identify emotions in self.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to learn about the Alphabet Cards.
Help children name the pictures and letters for Aa, Bb, Cc, Dd, and Ee.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is that book about? Who’s your favorite character (person) in that story?
What special person do you like to be when you play dress up?
Choose a puzzle that you like. Can you put it together?
Can you draw a picture of yourself? Then let’s write your name on it.
What materials will you use to make a picture of yourself? You can use paint, crayons, or pencils.
What letter do you like? Trace it with your finger.
What do you like to build? How will you build it?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Talk About Feelings Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (feelings, share).
Begin story time by connecting the Mind Builder to Be Who You Are.
Read closely and talk about feelings.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Identify emotions in self.
Take another perspective.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to listen to what happened, look at a face, and guess what feeling the child is feeling—happy, sad, angry, and proud.
Have children create stories about feelings.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show me someone in your book and tell me how you think he feels?
Can you show me that you are angry without making a sound?
Can you make three faces that show three ways you might feel? Use a mirror to help you.
Can you draw a picture of a strong, proud lion?
Can you use colorful clay to make an animal that makes you happy?
What can you use to trace the first letter in your name?
Can you build a playground where you would like to play with friends?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Be Who You Are by Todd Parr. Copyright © 2016 by Todd Parr. Cover copyright © 2016 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, encourage children’s alphabet awareness with a song, and introduce vocabulary (brave).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How are you like the children in the book?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Participate in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Identify emotions in self.
Take another perspective.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to compare and contrast images to find faces that show the same feelings.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are you like someone in the book you are reading? Why is the book interesting?
Can you and a friend pretend you are twins and do the same thing?
Can you find two things that are the same? Can you find two things that are different?
Can you draw a picture to show two things that are the same?
How can you create two faces that are the same?
Look at the Magnetic Letters. Can you find uppercase C and lowercase c? Compare the two letters.
How can you use your blocks to show two things that look the same?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Be Who You Are by Todd Parr. Copyright © 2016 by Todd Parr. Cover copyright © 2016 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © LifetimeStock/Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I like to . . .

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about things they have been enjoying doing in preK, engage children in song and movement, and introduce vocabulary (square, catch).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts I Like to . . . and Be Who You Are.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: What makes us who we are?
Offer extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Participate in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Take another perspective.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

small-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I like to . . .

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children play a charades-like activity in which they act out what they like to do.
Have children guess what was being acted out.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Think about the book you are looking at. Can you tell me one thing that is special about it?
Pretend you are feeding a bunny. Why would that be special?
A square is a special shape. Can you think of a way to use connecting cubes to make a square shape?
Can you draw a picture that shows a book you like to look at?
Use a crayon to draw a square. Can you draw a bigger square?
Can you find the Magnetic Letter that is the first letter in your name? Can you trace it with your finger?
What kind of towers do you like to build? Do you like to make them high or low?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Be Who You Are by Todd Parr. Copyright © 2016 by Todd Parr. Cover copyright © 2016 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out introducing themselves to the class and to introduce vocabulary (learn).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What are some things you can do?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Participate in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Take another perspective.
Identify emotions in self.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Draw a picture that shows yourself with a happy face.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a book about yourself, what would you put in it?
Can you make up and show me different ways to clap your hands?
Can you use the pattern blocks to make something you think is special?
Can you draw a picture that shows a food you like to eat?
What color makes you feel happy? Can you create a picture using that color?
Can you use the Magnetic Letters to show letters in your first name?
How can you use the blocks to create a special place?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Be Who You Are by Todd Parr. Copyright © 2016 by Todd Parr. Cover copyright © 2016 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Identify similarities and differences between themselves and other children, inclusive of specific characteristics and cultural influences.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Identify similarities and differences between themselves and other children, inclusive of specific characteristics and cultural influences.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Identify similarities and differences between themselves and other children, inclusive of specific characteristics and cultural influences.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, moving to rhythms.
Retell or re-enact a story after it is read aloud.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
